bound to the south west by the Randell Shear and Railway Fault, and to the east by 
 The Karonie-Yindi Domain contains interleaved mafic and felsic volcanic-epiclastic 
 sedimentary units. A major volcanic centre, defined by abundant felsic volcanics and 
 quartz-aluminosilicate±chloritoid  rocks  (considered  to  represent  metamorphosed 
 alteration  assemblages),  occurs  in  the  central  portion  of  this  domain.  The  Karonie-

18.text: Yindi Domain is separated from the Jubilee Domain by the Avoca Shear to the west.

22.text: iron  formation.  This  domain  is  bounded  by  the  Randell  Shear  to  the  west  and  the

text:
Yindi Domain is separated from the Jubilee Domain by the Avoca Shear to the west. 
 The Mt Belches Domain in the southwest portion of the Kalgoorlie East Project is a 
 metasedimentary sequence comprised of greywacke (possible turbidites) and banded 
 iron  formation.  This  domain  is  bounded  by  the  Randell  Shear  to  the  west  and  the 
 Outcrop  is  minimal  due  to  transported  cover.  Extensive  colluvial  deposits  obscure 
 bedrock  in  the  southern  portion  of  the  project,  whilst  playa  and  associated  dune 
 deposits  of  Lake  Yindarlgooda  occur  in  the  northern  portion  of  the  project  area 
 Two  main  historical  gold-mining  centres,  Kurnalpi  and  Jubilee,  occur  in  close 
 proximity  to  the  Kalgoorlie  East  Project.  Kurnalpi,  approximately  10km  north  of 
 E28/1118,  contains  numerous  small  workings  of  alluvial  gold  and  narrow  gold 
 bearing  quartz  veins  associated  with  shears  in  basalt.  At  the  Jubilee  Mining  Centre 
 (~5km  north  of  E28/1116)  workings  are  associated  with  the  contact  between 
 sedimentary  rocks  and  schistose  ultramafics.  Gold  occurrences  near  Colour  Dam 
 (~3km north of E28/927) were tested by trial pit during the late ‘80s but mining was 
 discontinued  due  to  an  erratic  grade  distribution.  Minor  historical  gold  workings 
 associated  with  narrow  quartz  veins  occur  at  Gessner’s  Find  (430190E  6602400N) 
 and Rising Sun (427570E 6606260N).

text:
previously explored by Amax, Aquitaine and Esso. Au occurs in several subvertical 
 lodes associated with Cu, Pb and Zn sulphides in the primary zone. An erratic gold 
 distribution was noted in test mining, making the deposit uneconomic. 
 CRA Exploration (1990-93): Steeple Hill/Mooree Hill/Guildford Dam - WAMEX 
 I7271  –  Primarily  focused  on  base  metals,  although  Au  was  routinely  analysed. 
 Aircore  drilling  of  the  Swamp  Dam  prospect  intersected  8m  @  0.16ppm  Au  from 
 48m–EOH without intersecting bedrock (91SHAC009). Drill logs are brief and it is 
 considered that many of these holes may not have been drilled to blade refusal. At the 
 Big Dam prospect one diamond hole (92BDD001) tested a conductor with associated 
 Au, As and Cu anomalism identified in auger sampling. Elevated Cu and Zn levels 
 were intersected throughout the hole associated with graphitic±pyritic sediments and 
 CRA  Exploration  (1991-97):    Canegrass  Swamp/Christchurch  Dam/Randell 
 Siding  –  WAMEX  I7831,  I8390,  I9600  –  CRA’s  Christchurch  Dam  tenement 
 (E28/438),  is  broadly  coincident  with  the  southern  portion  of  the  Kalgoorlie  East 
 project. Auger sampling delineated a weak Au anomaly (Gundockerta South prospect) 
 ~5km to the west of E28/1129, which was followed up by 5 RAB holes. Following 
 disappointing  results  the  mafic/ultramafic  sequence  was  tested  by  a  series  of  broad 
 spaced  RAB  holes  in  an  effort  to  delineate  Ni/PGE  mineralization.  No  significant 
 intersections  were  reported.  Work  on  the  Canegrass  Swamp  project  yielded  some 
 significant  Au intersections  at the  Jubilee Prospect (including 16m @  6.09ppm and 
 22m  @  1.4ppm)  ~5km  to  the  NW  of  E28/1116.  RAB  drilling  of  the  Peninsula 
 prospect  directly  to  the  west  of  E28/1116  yielded  anomalous  Au  including  24m  @ 
 0.2ppm  and  4m  @  1.04ppm  associated  with  strongly  carbonate  altered

text:
Hampton Hill Mining NL (1994-98): Jurangie Hill gold exploration – WAMEX 
 I9725  –  Soil  sampling  and  RAB  drilling  identified  several  Au  anomalies  (>20ppb, 
 maximum  of  75ppb)  in  the  northern  portion  of  the  Kalgoorlie  East  Project 
 Striker/Talon (1994-99): Junction Lake-Jubilee - WAMEX I10454 – Initial work 
 focused on exploration for diamonds adjacent to the northern boundary of E28/1116. 
 Following negative results the focus switched to Ni and then Au. A total of 52 RAB 
 holes, 6 aircore holes and 14 RC holes were drilled with anomalous gold intersected 
 in  many holes. Some of the better Au intersections included 16m @ 0.48ppm from 
 34m (JUB03), 2m @ 7.04ppm from 36m (JUC09) and 18m @ 1.29ppm from 36m. 
 Talon  failed  to  find  an  interested  joint  venture  partner  and  the  tenements  were 
 Plato  Mining  (1994-2000):  Kurnalpi  -  WAMEX  I10765  –  Directly  north  of 
 to  Talon’s  project  detailed  above.  Anomalous  soil 
 geochemistry  (MMI)  was  tested  by  aircore  drilling,  giving  a  maximum  Au 
 Harmony (2001-2004): Transline JV Gold Project – As part a joint venture with 
 Avoca, Harmony (South  Kal Mines) completed work  over several  tenements  in  the 
 Kalgoorlie East project (E28/1003, E28/1116, E28/1117 and E28/1118). Broad spaced 
 auger  sampling  (640  m  x  80m)  over  E28/1003  revealed  a  coherent  low  order  Au 
 anomaly (maximum  34ppb) spatially associated with a BIF unit. This anomaly was 
 not  followed  up,  and  some  portions  of  the  tenement  covering  this  anomaly  were 
 subsequently surrendered. Reconnaissance aircore drilling (31 holes for 1404 metres) 
 targeted the interpreted fault separating the Jubilee and Kurnalpi Terranes (E28/1116). 
 This  drilling  returned  two  significant  Au  intersections,  2m  @  4.35ppm  from  46m 
 (03PPAC009) and 3m @ 0.81ppm from 54m – EOH (03PPAC010).

22.text: A program comprising 40 aircore drillholes was completed on E28/1116, following

23.text: up previous drilling by Harmony Gold of South Africa.  Several highly anomalous

24.text: values in the Harmony drilling (up to 5760ppb Au) were tested for repeatability by an

25.text: infill pattern in the current program (Figure 5).  The overall size of the mineralisation

26.text: system was also tested by drilling wider spaced lines to the north and south of the

27.text: previous drilling.  The high values intersected by Harmony were not achieved.  A

28.text: peak value of 433ppb Au was returned on the northern line of the program only, with

29.text: weakly anomalous gold and arsenic values on the other lines.  The system appears

30.text: open to the north and requires further investigation.

31.text: Composite samples over 5m downhole intervals, and 1m end of hole samples were

32.text: submitted to Genalysis Laboratories in Perth for analysis.  All samples were digested

33.text: with aqua regia.  Composites were analysed for Au via Graphite Furnace Atomic

34.text: Absorption Spectrometry (ETA), and for As via Flame Atomic Absorption

35.text: Spectrometry (AAS).  End of hole samples were analysed for Au, Ag, As, Bi, Mo, Pb,

36.text: Sb, and W via Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), and for Cu

37.text: and Zn via Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (AAS).

text:
to test for anomalies near an interpreted major NNW-trending fault.  Fewer samples 
 were taken than were hoped for due to lake levels impinging on the area of interest.  A 
 value of 22ppb Au was the highest returned. 
 Auger samples were analysed via ICP-MS for Au, Ag, As, Bi, Mo, Pb, Sb, and W, 
 and via Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES) for 
 A program comprising 40 aircore drillholes was completed on E28/1116, following 
 up previous drilling by Harmony Gold of South Africa.  Several highly anomalous 
 values in the Harmony drilling (up to 5760ppb Au) were tested for repeatability by an 
 infill pattern in the current program (Figure 5).  The overall size of the mineralisation 
 system was also tested by drilling wider spaced lines to the north and south of the 
 previous drilling.  The high values intersected by Harmony were not achieved.  A 
 peak value of 433ppb Au was returned on the northern line of the program only, with 
 weakly anomalous gold and arsenic values on the other lines.  The system appears 
 open to the north and requires further investigation. 
 Composite samples over 5m downhole intervals, and 1m end of hole samples were 
 submitted to Genalysis Laboratories in Perth for analysis.  All samples were digested 
 with aqua regia.  Composites were analysed for Au via Graphite Furnace Atomic 
 Absorption Spectrometry (ETA), and for As via Flame Atomic Absorption 
 Spectrometry (AAS).  End of hole samples were analysed for Au, Ag, As, Bi, Mo, Pb, 
 Sb, and W via Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), and for Cu 
 and Zn via Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (AAS). 
 9

11.text: determined via Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), and Cu

12.text: and Zn via Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (AAS). The results of these

13.text: analyses are included in digital format with this report.

 and Zn via Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (AAS). The results of these
